verses.text: Abraham traveled from there toward the region of the Negev, and settled between Kadesh and Shur. While he was staying in Gerar as a foreigner,
verses.comment: Gerar was a Philistine city. The migration of the patriarchs shows God's providence across different lands, reminiscent of the future Exodus (see Gen. 12:10; Ex. 3:8).

verses.text: Abraham said about Sarah his wife, 'She is my sister.' So Abimelech king of Gerar sent and took Sarah.
verses.comment: Abraham's repeated action (see Gen. 12:13) shows human weakness, yet God's faithfulness remains. The taking of Sarah draws parallels to Eve's temptation and the need for divine protection (1 Cor. 10:13).

verses.text: But God came to Abimelech in a dream by night and said, 'You are as good as dead because of the woman whom you have taken, for she is a man’s wife.'
verses.comment: God's intervention in dreams (cf. Gen. 31:24; Matt. 2:12) indicates that His sovereignty extends beyond Israel to all nations. Defending marriage prefigures Christ’s defense of the Church, His bride (Eph. 5:25-27).

verses.text: Now Abimelech had not come near her, so he said, 'Lord, will you destroy an innocent nation also?'
verses.comment: Abimelech appeals to God's justice. Compare with Abraham’s intercession for Sodom in Gen. 18:23. Here, the emphasis lies on conscience and natural law (Rom. 2:14-15).

verses.text: 'Didn’t he say to me, “She is my sister”? And she herself even said, “He is my brother.” I have done this with a clear heart and clean hands.'
verses.comment: Abimelech claims innocence, reflecting ethical awareness. 'Clean hands' evokes the call to moral purity (Ps. 24:4), a theme fulfilled in the New Covenant sacraments (1 John 1:7).

verses.text: Then God said to him in the dream, 'Yes, I know that you have done this with a pure heart. That is why I withheld you from sinning against Me; therefore I did not let you touch her.'
verses.comment: God’s prevenient grace operates to keep Abimelech from sin, anticipating the way God's grace empowers believers to resist evil (Phil. 2:13). God’s direct involvement emphasizes His holiness.

verses.text: Now therefore, restore the man’s wife; for he is a prophet, and he will pray for you and you will live. But if you do not restore her, know that you will surely die, you and all who are yours.'
verses.comment: Abraham's unique role as prophet and intercessor foreshadows the priestly mediation later fulfilled in Christ (Heb. 7:25). The sacramental power of intercessory prayer for others is alluded to (James 5:16).

verses.text: So Abimelech rose early in the morning and called all his servants, and told them all these things; and the men were greatly afraid.
verses.comment: Reverence and fear before God’s warnings illustrate the wisdom found in heeding divine revelation (Prov. 1:7).

verses.text: Then Abimelech called Abraham, and said to him, 'What have you done to us? How have I sinned against you, that you have brought upon me and my kingdom a great sin? You have done things to me that ought not to have been done.'
verses.comment: Abimelech rebukes Abraham. Even those outside God's covenant can discern moral truth (Rom. 2:14-15), emphasizing the universality of the moral law written on every heart.

verses.text: Abimelech also said to Abraham, 'What were you thinking, that you did this thing?'
verses.comment: A call for moral reasoning. This highlights human responsibility in cooperating with God’s will (Phil. 2:12-13).

verses.text: Abraham said, 'I thought, Surely there is no fear of God in this place, and they will kill me because of my wife.'
verses.comment: Abraham confesses his fear and lack of trust. This demonstrates the need for ongoing sanctification, as even the greatest saints make imperfect moral judgments.

verses.text: And besides, she really is my sister, the daughter of my father but not the daughter of my mother, and she became my wife.
verses.comment: Abraham's explanation reflects ancient Near Eastern customs. God's progressive revelation clarifies moral standards over time (Acts 17:30).

verses.text: When God caused me to wander from my father’s house, I said to her, "This is the kindness you must show me: at every place to which we come, say of me, ‘He is my brother.’"
verses.comment: Abraham’s wandering prefigures the spiritual journey of faith, later embodied in Israel’s pilgrim experience (Heb. 11:8-10).

verses.text: Then Abimelech took sheep and oxen, male servants and female servants, and gave them to Abraham, and he returned Sarah his wife to him.
verses.comment: Restitution with gifts reflects the importance of reparation and making right relations, a theme key in both Old and New Testament morality (Matt. 5:23-24).

verses.text: Abimelech said, 'See, my land is before you; settle wherever you please.'
verses.comment: Abimelech’s generosity echoes Melchizedek’s blessing in Gen. 14:18–20, pointing forward to hospitality as a mark of true faith (Heb. 13:2).

verses.text: To Sarah he said, 'Look, I have given your brother a thousand pieces of silver. This is to vindicate you before all who are with you. You are completely cleared.'
verses.comment: The gift serves to publicly restore Sarah’s dignity. Spiritual restoration and making amends parallel New Testament teaching on confession and reconciliation (John 8:11).

verses.text: Then Abraham prayed to God, and God healed Abimelech, and his wife and female servants, so they could have children again.
verses.comment: Intercessory prayer mediates God’s healing, prefiguring Christ’s mediation and the Church’s ministry of reconciliation (James 5:14-16).

verses.text: For the LORD had closed all the wombs in the household of Abimelech because of Sarah, Abraham’s wife.
verses.comment: God’s sovereign opening and closing of wombs demonstrates His authority over life. This continues the theme of barrenness and miraculous birth found throughout Scripture (cf. Luke 1:7, 1:36), often paralleling salvation history.
